reports.label: Overstated resilience and unbiasedness vs. ACE wrap handling in Section 6
reports.explanation: Section 6 asserts that lost ACKs immediately recover all ECN markings without bias, yet the normative sections specify that when using the 3-bit ACE field, counter wrap-around forces the sender to apply conservative, potentially biased estimates.
justification: Section 6 unconditionally claims that counters allow full, unbiased recovery even after ACK loss.
Normative text in Section 3.2.2.5.2 and Appendix A.2 requires that if the 3-bit ACE counter may have wrapped, the sender must take the 'safest likely case' which can overestimate CE marks.

Multiple experts (Temporal, Quantitative, Deontic, CrossRFC, and Boundary) note that in scenarios without AccECN Options and under heavy ACK loss the information recovery is inherently approximate and potentially biased.

snippets.text: Section 6 'Resilience': All information is provided based on counters. Therefore if ACKs are lost, the counters on the first ACK following the losses allows the Data Sender to immediately recover the number of the ECN markings that it missed.

Section 6 'Resilience against Bias': Because feedback is based on repetition of counters, random losses do not remove any information, they only delay it. Therefore, even though some ACKs are change‑triggered, random losses will not alter the proportions of the different ECN markings in the feedback.
Section 3.2.2.5.2: When the 3‑bit ACE field might have cycled, the sender SHOULD deem whether it cycled by taking the safest likely case under the prevailing conditions.
Section 8: Without AccECN Options, the essential feedback part offers only limited resilience to long runs of ACK loss, requiring conservative assumptions about counter wrap.

summary: (E1) Section 6 asserts immediate recovery of ECN markings after ACK loss.
(E2) Section 6 states that random losses only delay information, without causing bias.
(E3) Normative text mandates a conservative interpretation when the 3‑bit counter may have wrapped.
(E4) Section 8 limits resilience in ACE‑only mode, implying potential loss of exact information.

reports.fix_direction: Revise Section 6 to qualify its claims on resilience and unbiasedness by indicating that these properties hold only when AccECN Options are present and counter wrap does not occur; otherwise, conservative estimation is applied.
reports.severity_basis: The misleading summary may cause implementers and algorithm designers to assume ideal, lossless feedback, while the normative text clearly provides for ambiguity and overestimation in extreme ACK loss scenarios.

reports.label: Overstated ordering and timeliness guarantees vs. normative ACK emission rules in Section 6
reports.explanation: Section 6 claims that the order of arriving ECN marks is strictly preserved and that an ACK is sent immediately on any marking change, but the normative specification only recommends change-triggered ACKs (a SHOULD) and permits ACK coalescing under performance constraints.
justification: Section 6 unconditionally asserts immediate and ordered ACK responses for each change in ECN marking.

The normative rules (Section 3.2.2.5.1) define change-triggered ACKs as a SHOULD with allowed exceptions, for example when LRO/GRO or high-performance offload causes multiple packets to be processed together.
Experts across Temporal, CrossRFC, and Boundary analyses note that under practical circumstances, ordering and timeliness may be degraded relative to the ideal described in Section 6.

snippets.text: Section 6 'Ordering': The order in which marks arrive at the Data Receiver is preserved in AccECN feedback, because the Data Receiver is expected to send an ACK immediately whenever a different mark arrives.

Section 6 'Timeliness': While the same ECN markings are arriving continually at the Data Receiver, it can defer ACKs as TCP does normally, but it will immediately send an ACK as soon as a different ECN marking arrives.
Section 3.2.2.5.1: Change-Triggered ACKs are defined with a SHOULD, allowing for exceptions such as when multiple packets are coalesced via LRO/GRO, which can lead to fewer, aggregated ACKs.

summary: (E5) Section 6 implies that the order of ECN marks is preserved by immediate ACK transmission.
(E6) Section 6 states that an immediate ACK will be sent upon a change in ECN marking.
(E7) Normative text clarifies that change-triggered ACKs are not mandatory, permitting ACK aggregation under performance constraints.

reports.fix_direction: Modify Section 6 to state that ordering and timeliness guarantees depend on the receiver fully implementing change-triggered ACKs, and that performance optimizations (e.g., LRO/GRO) may lead to coalesced ACKs with reduced ordering fidelity.
reports.severity_basis: The absolute language in Section 6 could mislead implementers into over-relying on precise, immediate feedback, which is not guaranteed under the normative guidelines.
